   Taxonomic position; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Neoperlops [China /  / Distribution; taxonomic review]. 
   Neoperlops gressitti [Guangxi Zhuang /  / New record; systematics]. 
   Neoperlops triangulatus [Guangxi Zhuang /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Plecoptera

   p. 409].

PT J
AN ZOOR15606042644
DT Article
TI Spirlins of the southern Black Sea basin, with the description of a new
   species (Teleostei: Leuciscidae).
AU Kaya, Cuneyt (cnytkaya@yahoo.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4763
IS 3
PS 419-428
PD Apr 14 2020
PY 2020
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Alburnoides turani, new species, from the Filyos River drainage is
   described and the distribution of the nine other Alburnoides species
   known from the southern Black Sea basin is revised. Alburnoides turani
   is distinguished by having a naked ventral keel, or the keel is covered
   with 1-3 scales between the posterior pelvic-fin base and the anus, an
   interoibital distance wider than the eye diameter and the snout length,
   48-55 total lateral-line scales, 5-6 scale rows between the analfin
   origin and the lateral line, 131/2 -141/2 branched anal-fin rays, and
   41-42 total vertebrae.
C1 Kaya, Cuneyt; Recep Tayyip Erdogan Univ, Fac Fisheries, Rize, TR-53100,
   Turkey, Turkey.
EM cnytkaya@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia
DE Alburnoides [Turkey / Black Sea & Marmara Sea basins / Key to species] [
   / Black Sea basin / Distribution; systematics]. 
   Alburnoides turani [Turkey /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Cypriniformes, Cyprinidae
OR Alburnoides (Cyprinidae): [Key to species, Turkey, Black Sea & Marmara
   Sea basins, Modified key, p. 420]. 
   Alburnoides turani (Cyprinidae): [Sp nov, Turkey, P. 421].

DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15606042645
DT Article
TI Discovery of Viridotheres Manning, 1996 in the southwestern Pacific and
   first record of Discorsotheres camposi Ahyong, 2018 from New Caledonia
   (Crustacea: Brachyura: Pinnotheridae).
AU Ahyong, Shane T. (shane.ahyong@austmus.gov.au) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4763
IS 3
PS 429-434
PD Apr 14 2020
PY 2020
LA English
U1 2
U2 2
AB The pinnotherid crab genus, Viridotheres Manning, 1996, is recorded for
   the first time from the southwestern Pacific in the new species, V.
   asaphis, described based on specimens from Australia and New Caledonia.
   The new species most closely resembles V. sanguinolariae (Pillai, 1951)
   from India, differing chiefly in the proportional length of the walking
   legs; both species are hosted by bivalve molluscs of the family
   Psammobiidae, but of different genera. The pinnotherid crab
   Discorsotheres camposi Ahyong, 2018, an associate of the bivalve
   Spondylus, is recorded for the first time from New Caledonia. Fifteen
   species of pinnotherid are now known from Australian waters and five
   from New Caledonia.
C1 Ahyong, Shane T.; Australian Museum, 1 William St, Sydney, NSW, 2010,
   Australia, Australia.
EM shane.ahyong@austmus.gov.au
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Associations; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Asaphis dichotoma [Associations / Viridotheres asaphis (Crustacea) / New
   associate species] [South Pacific / Australia, Queensland / New
   associated crustacean species]. 
   Asaphis violascens [Associations / Viridotheres asaphis (Crustacea) /
   New associate species] [South Pacific / New Caledonia / New associated
   crustacean species]. 
   Discorsotheres; Discorsotheres camposi [Associations / Spondylus varius
   (Mollusca) / New record; systematics] [South Pacific / New Caledonia /
   Molluscan associates]. 
   Spondylus varius [Associations / Discorsotheres camposi (Crustacea) /
   New record] [ / Discorsotheres (Crustacea) / ] [South Pacific / New
   Caledonia / Crustacean associates]. 
   Viridotheres [South Pacific / Australia & New Caledonia / New record;
   systematics].

U1 0

AB The genus Rapisma McLachlan, 1866 (montane lacewings) is a rare and
   little known group of the family Ithonidae (Insecta: Neuroptera). There
   have been 21 described species of Rapisma, and all of them are
   distributed from East Asia, South Asia and Southeast Asia. Here I report
   a new species of Rapisma from northwestern Yunnan, China, namely Rapisma
   weixiense sp. nov. The new species belongs to a group of Rapisma species
   with very short antennae.

DT Article
TI A Species-level Phylogeny of Old World Fruit Bats with a New
   Higher-level Classification of the Family Pteropodidae.
AU Cunha Almeida, Francisca
   Simmons, Nancy B.
   Giannini, Norberto P.
SO American Museum Novitates
VL 3950
PS 1-24
PD Apr 13 2020
PY 2020
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Old World fruit bats (Chiroptera: Yinpterochiroptera: Pteropodidae) are
   a diverse radiation endemic to the tropics of Africa, Asia, Australia,
   and nearby island archipelagos. Recent molecular analyses have provided
   considerable resolution of phylogenetic relationships within this group,
   but many points of uncertainty have remained including the position of
   several enigmatic taxa (e.g., Notopteris, Eidolon), relationships among
   species in more diverse subfamilies and genera (e.g., Pteropodinae,
   Pteropus, Epomophorus), and topology of the backbone of the tree. Here
   we provide a new, synthetic analysis including representatives of all 45
   currently recognized genera and enhanced sampling in several speciose
   genera. Our matrix included four nuclear genes regions (vWF, RAG1, RAG2,
   and BRCA1) and four mitochondrial gene loci (Cytb, tRNA valine, 12S
   rRNA, and 16S rRNA) for a total of >8000 bp including new sequence data
   for 13 species. Maximum likelihood and Bayesian analyses resulted in
   trees supporting recognition of six main suprageneric clades similar in
   content to those identified in our previous studies. We did not recover
   strong support for relationships among the main clades along the
   backbone of the tree, but identified many well-supported clades within
   all of the major groups. Based on these results, we propose a new
   classification for Pteropodidae comprising eight subfamilies and 14
   tribes, and including several new and/or replacement higher-level
   taxonomic names for which we provide morphological diagnoses.
C1 Cunha Almeida, Francisca; CONICET, Inst Ecol Genet & Evoluc Buenos
   Aires, Buenos Aires, DF, Argentina, Argentina.
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology
SN 0003-0082; 1937-352X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type genus; Diagnosis; Available
   name; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Genetics; Evolution
DE Pteropodidae [Molecular genetics / Mitochondrial gene sequences /
   taxonomic revision] [Phylogeny /  / ]. 
TN Bats; Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Chiroptera, Pteropodidae
OR Pteropodidae (Chiroptera): [Classification, New higher-level
   classification, p. 11]. 
   Desmalopex - Miller 1907 (Pteropodidae): [Referred to, New tribe
   Pteralopini, p. 14]. 
   Dobsoniini - Andersen 1912 (Pteropodidae): [Emended diagnosis, P. 16]. 
   Epomophorus - Bennett 1835 (Pteropodidae): [Emended diagnosis, P. 16]. 
   Harpyionycterini - Miller 1907 (Pteropodidae): [Diagnosis, P. 15]. 
   Macroglossinae - Harris 1939 (Pteropodidae): [Preoccupied name replaced
   by, Macroglossusinae, p. 13]. 
   Macroglossusinae (Pteropodidae): [Nom nov, For Macroglossinae Harris
   1939, p. 13]. 
   Megaerops - Peters 1865 (Pteropodidae): [Emended diagnosis, P. 18]. 
   Melonycterini (Pteropodidae): [Tribe nov, Of subfamily Pteropodinae,
   Type genus Melonycteris Dobson 1877, p. 14]. 
   Melonycteris - Dobson 1877 (Pteropodidae): [Designated type genus for
   new tribe, Melonycterini, p. 14]. 
   Mirimiri - Helgen 2007 (Pteropodidae): [Referred to, New tribe
   Pteralopini, p. 14]. 
   Nesonycteris - Thomas 1887 (Pteropodidae): [Referred to, New tribe
   Melonycterini, p. 14].

   subfamily, Notopterisinae, p. 12].

   1859, p. 12]. 
   Pteralopex - Thomas 1888 (Pteropodidae): [Designated type genus for new
   tribe, Pteralopini, p. 14]. 
   Pteralopini (Pteropodidae): [Tribe nov, Of subfamily Pteropodinae, Type
   genus Pteralopex Thomas 1888, p. 14].

TI A new species of rake-legged mite, Caeculus cassiopeiae (Prostigmata,
   Caeculidae), from Canada and a systematic analysis of its genus.
AU Bernard, Jared (bernardj@hawaii.edu) 
   Lumley, Lisa M.
   Buck, Matthias
   Cobb, Tyler P.
SO ZooKeys
VL 926
PS 1-23
PD Apr 13 2020
PY 2020
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Caeculus Dufour (Prostigmata, Caeculidae) contains 19
   previously described species, most of which are found in North America,
   and for which no comprehensive phylogenetic treatment exists. Here, one
   new species from Alberta, Canada, is described: Caeculus cassiopeiae
   Bernard&Lumley, sp. nov., and another caeculid known to be present in
   Canada is documented. The new species is characterized within the genus
   with a character state matrix, from which an updated key is produced. A
   systematic analysis of all 20 species based on morphological and
   geographical distribution traits obtained from literature represents the
   first phylogenetic review of the genus.

   Alysiinae) are reviewed and keyed. A new genus (Neodiasta gen. nov.) is

DT Article
TI A new species of hagfish, Eptatretus wandoensis sp. nov. (Agnatha,
   Myxinidae), from the southwestern Sea of Korea.
AU Song, Young Sun
   Kim, Jin-Koo (taengko@hanmail.net) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 926
PS 81-94
PD Apr 13 2020
PY 2020
LA English
U1 4
U2 4
AB Four specimens of the five-gilled white mid-dorsal line hagfish,
   Eptatretus wandoensis sp. nov. were recently collected from the
   southwestern Sea of Korea (Wando). This new species has five pairs of
   gill apertures, 14-18 prebranchial slime pores, 4 branchial slime pores,
   a dark brown back with a white mid-dorsal line and a white belly. These
   hagfish are similar to Eptatretus burgeri and Eptatretus minor in having
   a white mid-dorsal line, but can be readily distinguished by the numbers
   of gill apertures (5 vs. 6-7), gill pouches (5 vs. 6), and prebranchial
   slime pores (14-18 vs. > 18), as well as the body color (dark brown back
   vs. gray or brown pale). In terms of genetic differences, Eptatretus
   wandoensis could be clearly distinguished from E. burgeri (0.9% in 16S
   rRNA and 8.5% in cytochrome c oxidase subunit I sequences) and E. minor
   (4.5% and 13.9%).
C1 Kim, Jin-Koo; Pukyong Natl Univ, Dept Marine Biol, Busan, 48513, South
   Korea, South Korea.
EM taengko@hanmail.net
OI Kim, Jin-Koo/0000-0002-8499-406X
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970

DE Eptatretus wandoensis [North Pacific / South Korea / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Agnatha, Myxini, Myxiniformes
OR Eptatretus wandoensis (Myxiniformes): [Sp nov, South Korea (marine), P.
   83].

DT Article
TI Painted black: Iguana melanoderma (Reptilia, Squamata, Iguanidae) a new
   melanistic endemic species from Saba and Montserrat islands (Lesser
   Antilles).
AU Breuil, Michel
   Schikorski, David
   Vuillaume, Barbara
   Krauss, Ulrike
   Morton, Matthew N.
   Corry, Elizabeth
   Bech, Nicolas
   Jelic, Misel
   Grandjean, Frederic (frederic.grandjean@univ-poitiers.fr) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 926
PS 95-131
PD Apr 13 2020
PY 2020
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Lesser Antilles, in the Eastern Caribbean, is inhabited by three
   Iguana species: the Lesser Antillean iguana Iguana delicatissima, which
   is endemic to the northernmost islands of the Lesser Antilles, the
   introduced common iguana from South America, Iguana iguana iguana,
   represented also by the two newly described endemic subspecies Iguana
   iguana sanctaluciae from Saint Lucia and Iguana iguana insularis from
   Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, and Grenada, and the introduced Iguana
   rhinolopha from Central America. Drawing on both morphological and
   genetic data, this paper describes the Iguana populations from Saba and
   Montserrat as a new species, Iguana melanoderma. This species is
   recognized on the basis of the following combination of characteristics:
   private microsatellite alleles, unique mitochondrial ND4 haplotypes, a
   distinctive black spot between the eye and tympanum, a dorsal carpet
   pattern on juveniles and young adults, a darkening of body coloration
   with aging (except for the anterior part of the snout), a black dewlap,
   pink on the jowl, the high number of large tubercular nape scales, fewer
   than ten medium sized-triangular dewlap spikes, high dorsal spikes, and
   lack of horns on the snout. This new melanistic taxon is threatened by
   unsustainable harvesting (including for the pet trade) and both
   competition and hybridization from escaped or released invasive alien
   iguanas (I. iguana iguana and I. rhinolopha) from South and Central
   America, respectively. The authors call for action to conserve Iguana
   melanoderma in Saba and Montserrat and for further research to
   investigate its relationship to other melanistic iguanas from the Virgin
   Islands and coastal islands of Venezuela.
C1 Grandjean, Frederic; Univ Poitiers, Lab Ecol & Biol Interact, 5 Rue
   Albert Turpin, Poitiers, F-86073, France, France.
EM frederic.grandjean@univ-poitiers.fr
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   Central America; West Indies
DE Iguana melanoderma [Montserrat /  / New species] [Saba /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Iguanidae
OR Iguana melanoderma (Iguanidae): [Sp nov, Saba, P. 107]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15606042929
OA DOAJ Gold, Green Published
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR15606042930
PM 32336923
DT Article
TI A new species of Cyrtodactylus (Squamata, Gekkonidae) from Cambodia's
   Prey Lang Wildlife Sanctuary.
AU Neang, Thy
   Henson, Adam
   Stuart, Bryan L. (bryan.stuart@naturalsciences.org) 
SO ZooKeys
VL 926
PS 133-158
PD Apr 13 2020
PY 2020
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Cyrtodactylus phnomehiensis sp. nov. is described from Phnom Chi, an
   isolated mountain in Prey Lang Wildlife Sanctuary, Kampong Thom
   Province, Cambodia. The new species is recognized by having a unique
   combination of morphological characters, including snout-vent length
   76.1-80.7 mm; paravertebral tubercles 31-36; ventral scales 45-54;
   enlarged femoral scales 0-8, without pores; enlarged precloacal scales
   7-10, bearing pores 4-5 in males, pits 1-7 in females; the posterior
   border of nuchal loop unbroken and pointed, bordered anteriorly and
   posteriorly by a broad yellow or yellowish white hand; and yellow spots
   on top of head. The new species also represents a divergent
   mitochondrial DNA lineage within the C irregularis complex that is
   closely related to C ziegleri, but the phylogenetic relationships among
   the new species and two divergent mitochondrial subclades within C
   ziegleri arc not resolved based on available sequence data. qrtodaaylus
   phnomchiensis sp. nov. is the only member of the C irregularis complex
   known to occur west of the Mekong River. The new species may be endemic
   to Phnom Chi, and likely faces imminent conservation threats.
C1 Stuart, Bryan L.; North Carolina Museum Nat Sci, 11 West Jones St,
   Raleigh, NC, 27601, USA, USA.
EM bryan.stuart@naturalsciences.org
SC Zoology
SN 1313-2970
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Cyrtodactylus phnomchiensis [Cambodia /  / New species]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Gekkonidae
OR Cyrtodactylus phnomchiensis (Gekkonidae): [Sp nov, Cambodia, P. 139].

DT Article
TI A new species of Syllis Grube, 1850 including transcriptomic data and an
   updated phylogeny of Syllinae (Annelida: Syllidae).
AU Passos Ribeiro, Rannyele (rannyele.passos@uam.es) 
   Ponz-Segrelles, Guillermo
   Helm, Conrad
   Egger, Bernhard
   Aguado, M. Teresa
SO Marine Biodiversity
VL 50
IS 3
PS 1-16
PD Apr 11 2020
PY 2020
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Syllis Grube, 1850 (Syllidae, Annelida) from marine
   aquaria is described in this study, including information about its life
   cycle, laboratory cultures, transcriptomic data, and an updated
   phylogeny of the group. Syllis malaquini sp. nov. is diagnosed by a
   slender body with a colour pattern consisting of dorsal dark lines on
   each segment and a dark stain on the anterior region of the prostomium,
   blades of falciger compound chaetae bidentate, with proximal and distal
   teeth of similar length, short dorsal cirri with alternation in length
   in the anterior body, one bidentate ventral simple chaeta and one dorsal
   simple chaeta with a distal notch in posterior parapodia, and thin
   pointed aciculae. Additionally, we present an updated molecular
   phylogeny of Syllinae, which indicates that Syllis malaquini sp. nov.
   clusters with specimens of Typosyllis gerundensis (Alos&Campoy, 1981),
   Syllis hyalina Grube, 1863, and Syllis armillaris (Muller, 1776) from
   the Mediterranean Sea. The new species is maintained in aquaria and
   petri dish cultures in the laboratory, and its life cycle was observed
   and documented. Syllis malaquini sp. nov. reproduces sexually by
   schizogamy and asexually by fission. Furthermore, transcriptomic data of
   the new species is provided as a useful tool for further studies and
   comparative approaches. Syllis malaquini sp. nov. is an interesting
   organism to study reproduction and regeneration in syllids.
C1 Passos Ribeiro, Rannyele; Univ Autonoma Madrid, Dept Biol, Madrid,
   E-28049, Spain, Spain.
EM rannyele.passos@uam.es
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1867-1616; 1867-1624
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Genetics; Evolution
DE Syllinae [Molecular genetics / mtDNA COI & 16S rRNA genes / ] [Phylogeny
   / Molecular phylogeny / ]. 
TN Annelids; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Annelida, Polychaeta
OR Syllinae (Polychaeta). 
   Syllis malaquini (Polychaeta): [Sp nov, Type locality not given, P. 3].

TI Three new species and one new record of Torrenticolidae (Acari,
   Hydrachnidia) from Wuyishan with an updated key for Chinese fauna.
AU Gu, Xin-Yao
   Jin, Dao-Chao
   Guo, Jian-Jun (agr.xyku18@gzu.edu.cn) 
SO European Journal of Taxonomy
VL 625
PS 1-23
PD Apr 10 2020
PY 2020
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB New data of Torrenticolidae Piersig, 1902 are presented in this paper
   from Wuyishan National Nature Reserve, P. R. China. Three new species,
   Torrenticola suptilisrostrum Gu&Guo sp. nov., Torrenticola spinextension
   Gu&Guo sp. nov. and Torrenticola wuyiensis Gu&Guo sp. nov. are described
   and illustrated in detail, and one new record for Chinese fauna is
   given, Torrenticola dentifera Wiles, 1991, which was originally
   described from Malaysia. In addition, an updated key is provided to all
   species of Torrenticolidae in China.
C1 Guo, Jian-Jun; Guizhou Univ, Inst Entomol, Guiyang, 550025, China,
   China.
EM agr.xyku18@gzu.edu.cn
RI Guo, Jianjun/AAP-4437-2020

PT J
AN ZOOR15608054775

DT Article
TI Pedobacter schmidteae sp. nov., a new bacterium isolated from the
   microbiota of the planarian Schmidtea mediterranea.
AU Kangale, Luis Johnson
   Raoult, Didier
   Ghigo, Eric (eric.ghigo@gmail.com) 
   Fournier, Pierre-Edouard
SO Scientific Reports
VL 10
IS 1
PS 6113
PD Apr 9 2020
PY 2020
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Pedobacter schmidteae sp. nov. strain EGT (Collection de Souches de
   l'Unite des Rickettsie CSUR P6417=Coleccion Espanola de Cultivos Tipo
   CECT 9771) is a new Pedobacter species isolated from the planarian
   Schmidtea mediterranea. Schmidtea mediterranea are flatworms living in
   freshwater and exhibiting an unusual ability to regenerate amputated
   parts. To date, the gut microbiota of Schmidtea mediterranea remains
   poorly studied. Here, via the culturomics strategy that consists in
   using diversified culture conditions, we isolated a new bacterium,
   strain EG, that we characterized using the taxono-genomics approach that
   combines phenotypic assays and genome sequencing and analysis. Strain EG
   exhibits a 16S rRNA sequence similarity of 98.29% with Pedobacter
   nyackensis strain NWG-II14T, its closest neighbour with standing in
   nomenclature. It is an aerobic bacterium belonging to the family
   Sphingobacteriaceae. Colonies are small, round, smooth and transparent.
   Bacterial cells are Gram-negative, rod-shaped, motile and
   non-spore-forming bacilli with positive catalase and oxidase activities.
   The genome sequence is 6,198,518 bp-long with a G+C content of 41.13%,
   and the Ortho-ANI and dDDH values when compared to P. nyackensis are
   77.34% and 21.50%, respectively. Strain EGT exhibits unique
   characteristics that classify it as the type strain of new bacterial
   species for which we propose the name Pedobacter schmidteae sp. nov.
C1 Ghigo, Eric; Aix Marseille Univ, AP HM, Marseille, France, France.
EM eric.ghigo@gmail.com
OI Fournier, Pierre-Edouard/0000-0001-8463-8885
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 2045-2322
BD Associations
DE Schmidtea mediterranea [Associations / Pedobacter schmidteae (bacterium)
   / New bacterial species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Platyhelminths
ST Animalia, Platyhelminthes, Turbellaria
OR Schmidtea mediterranea (Turbellaria). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15608054775
OA DOAJ Gold, Green Published
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15607048429
DT Article
TI Geographic variation in composition of metazoan parasite
   infracommunities in Galaxias maculatus Jenyns 1842 (Osmeriformes:
   Galaxiidae) in southern Chile (38-47[degree] S).
AU George-Nascimento, Mario
   Lopez-Rodriguez, Ruby
   Gorski, Konrad (konrad.gorsKi@uach.cl) 
SO Revista Chilena de Historia Natural
VL 93
IS 1
PS 2
PD Apr 9 2020
PY 2020
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Galaxias maculatus is an abundant freshwater fish species in Chilean
   continental waters where it plays important ecological functions, yet
   few parasitological records of this species exist in Chile and all of
   them cover a very limited geographic range. The objective of this study
   was to assess large scale geographic variation in composition of
   parasite infracommunities of Galaxias maculatus. Specifically, parasite
   infracommunities of this species were compared among 11 locations across
   9 degrees of latitude and 3 ecosystem types (lake, river and estuary).
   Most taxa found had been previously reported in Chile and Argentina.
   However, this is the first report for Tylodelphys sp. in this host in
   Chile. Furthermore, the cranial parasite Tylodelphys sp. had the highest
   overall prevalence and abundance compared to other parasite species.
   Despite the fact that the abundance of Tylodelphys sp. was not
   significantly correlated with Fulton's condition factor of fish,
   infected fish seem to have a better body condition compared to
   uninfected ones. The most important source of variation in composition
   of infracommunities was the sampling location. Furthermore, fish from
   lakes have a different composition of parasite infracommunities mainly
   due to higher abundances of Tylodelphys sp.
C1 Gorski, Konrad; Univ Catolica Santisima Concepcion, Fac Ciencias,
   Concepcion, Chile, Chile.
EM konrad.gorsKi@uach.cl

   Biology

   Neotropical region; South America
